description: Involved in thermoregulation and defensive behaviors. Contains neurons that respond to changes in body temperature and mediate heat dissipation responses.

A critical hub for energy homeostasis containing POMC and AgRP neurons that regulate hunger and satiety. Sits near the median eminence with privileged access to circulating hormones like leptin and ghrelin.
Sexually dimorphic nucleus essential for the LH surge that triggers ovulation in females. Contains kisspeptin neurons that regulate the reproductive axis.
Integrates circadian and metabolic signals to coordinate feeding behavior and energy expenditure. Important relay for SCN outputs controlling rhythmic behaviors.
Known as the feeding center, contains orexin/hypocretin neurons critical for arousal and reward. Damage causes hypophagia while stimulation promotes feeding.
Involved in sleep-wake regulation and thermoregulation. Contains warm-sensitive neurons and GABAergic sleep-promoting populations.
Circumventricular organ where hypothalamic releasing hormones enter the portal blood system. Lacks a blood-brain barrier, allowing neuroendocrine communication.
Processes pheromonal and social chemosensory information from the vomeronasal organ. Critical for innate social behaviors including mating and aggression.
Central regulator of male sexual behavior and parental care. Sexually dimorphic structure that differs in size between males and females.
Controls thermoregulation, sleep, and parental behavior. Contains GABAergic neurons that promote sleep by inhibiting arousal centers.
Contains histaminergic neurons that promote wakefulness and arousal. Also involved in thermoregulation and autonomic responses to stress.
Mediates defensive behaviors in response to predator threats. Receives input from the amygdala and projects to the periaqueductal gray.
Key node in reproductive behavior circuits, particularly in males. Activated during social encounters and involved in territorial aggression.
Master controller of the stress response via CRH neurons projecting to the pituitary. Also contains oxytocin and vasopressin magnocellular neurons.
Dorsal subdivision of PVH containing parvocellular neurons. Projects to brainstem and spinal cord for autonomic control.
Contains somatostatin neurons that inhibit growth hormone release. Part of the periventricular zone lining the third ventricle.
Involved in neuroendocrine regulation in the caudal hypothalamus. Contains neurons projecting to the median eminence.
Rostral periventricular zone involved in GnRH regulation. Contains kisspeptin neurons in rodents that regulate puberty onset.
The master circadian pacemaker of the brain, entrained by light via the retinohypothalamic tract. Contains approximately 20000 neurons whose molecular clocks synchronize daily rhythms.
Circumventricular organ that senses blood-borne signals related to fluid balance. Critical for thirst and cardiovascular regulation via angiotensin II detection.
Contains magnocellular neurons producing oxytocin and vasopressin. Projects directly to the posterior pituitary for hormone release into circulation.
Part of the basal ganglia circuitry involved in movement control. Dysfunction is implicated in Parkinson's disease and is a target for deep brain stimulation.
Located in the tuberal region, involved in feeding regulation. Contains neurons expressing receptors for metabolic hormones.
Classical satiety center that inhibits feeding when stimulated. Also critical for female sexual behavior and defensive aggression.
Subthalamic region receiving diverse inputs and involved in attention and arousal. Contains GABAergic neurons that gate sensory information flow.
Transition zone between the amygdala and neighboring structures. Involved in processing emotional and olfactory information.
Key structure in the ventral striatum mediating reward and motivation. Central to the mesolimbic dopamine pathway and implicated in addiction.
Part of the anterior thalamic group relaying head direction signals. Critical for spatial navigation and episodic memory via connections with the hippocampus.
Small preoptic nucleus involved in autonomic regulation. Contributes to thermoregulatory and sleep-wake circuits.
Anterior thalamic relay for limbic circuits. Involved in learning and memory through connections with the hippocampal formation and cingulate cortex.
Scattered magnocellular neurons near the supraoptic nucleus. Produces oxytocin and vasopressin, supplementing the main supraoptic nucleus output.
Anterior thalamic nucleus conveying hippocampal and mammillary body inputs. Important for spatial memory and head direction signaling.
Preoptic region involved in fluid balance and cardiovascular regulation. Contains osmosensitive neurons that modulate vasopressin release.

full_name: Bed nucleus of the anterior commissure
description: Small nucleus associated with the anterior commissure fiber tract. Involved in interhemispheric communication and limbic processing.

full_name: Bed nuclei of the stria terminalis
description: Extended amygdala structure mediating sustained anxiety and stress responses. Integrates limbic and hypothalamic circuits for autonomic and neuroendocrine output.
Major output nucleus of the amygdala controlling fear and anxiety responses. Projects to brainstem and hypothalamus for autonomic and behavioral defense reactions.
Intralaminar thalamic nucleus involved in arousal and attention. Projects broadly to the striatum and cortex to modulate wakefulness.
Midline thalamic nucleus projecting to the prefrontal cortex and striatum. Involved in arousal, cognitive flexibility, and limbic processing.
The dorsal striatum in rodents, integrating cortical inputs for action selection and motor planning. Contains medium spiny neurons of the direct and indirect basal ganglia pathways.
Transitional structure between the piriform cortex and deeper brain regions. Processes olfactory information and may contribute to seizure propagation.
Ventral extension of the striatum bridging the caudate-putamen and nucleus accumbens. Contains medium spiny neurons involved in limbic-motor integration.
Basal ganglia nucleus in the indirect pathway that modulates motor output. GABAergic neurons project to the subthalamic nucleus to regulate movement.
Principal output nucleus of the basal ganglia. Tonically inhibits thalamic motor centers; reduced activity permits voluntary movement initiation.
Hypothalamic cells not mapped to a specific nucleus. May reside in transitional zones or diffuse hypothalamic areas.
Clusters of GABAergic neurons gating information flow between amygdala nuclei. Modulate fear learning and extinction by inhibiting central amygdala output.
Small nucleus between anterior thalamic nuclei. Relays limbic information and contributes to head direction and spatial processing circuits.
Transitional thalamic nucleus between anterior and midline groups. Involved in limbic relay functions connecting hippocampus and prefrontal cortex.
Thin layer between dorsal and ventral lateral geniculate nuclei. Relays photic and non-photic information to the suprachiasmatic nucleus for circadian entrainment.
Midline thalamic nucleus projecting to prefrontal cortex. Involved in cognitive and limbic processing, particularly reward-related decision making.
Transitional zone within the geniculate complex. Contributes to auditory and multisensory processing in the thalamus.
Thalamic nucleus relaying spatial and visual information to retrosplenial cortex. Involved in spatial orientation and navigation.
Primary thalamic relay for visual information from the retina to visual cortex. Organized in layers that process information from each eye.
Non-image-forming visual processing center. Involved in circadian photoentrainment and visuomotor responses rather than conscious vision.
Epithalamic structure encoding negative reward signals and aversion. Inhibits dopamine and serotonin neurons; hyperactivity is implicated in depression.
Mammillary body subdivision processing head direction signals. Projects to the anterior thalamus to support spatial navigation and memory.
Higher-order visual thalamic nucleus integrating cortical and tectal inputs. Involved in visual attention and processing of complex visual features.
Caudal division of the lateral septum involved in emotional regulation. Modulates stress responses and social behavior via hypothalamic projections.
Rostral division of the lateral septum processing hippocampal inputs. Involved in reward, social behavior, and modulation of anxiety.
Ventral division of the lateral septum with dense hypothalamic connections. Regulates feeding, aggression, and autonomic function.
Large-celled nucleus in the basal forebrain. Part of the cholinergic system providing modulatory input to cortex and hippocampus.
Major thalamic relay to prefrontal cortex. Critical for working memory, decision making, and flexible goal-directed behavior.
Midline preoptic nucleus involved in fluid homeostasis and thermoregulation. Integrates osmotic signals from circumventricular organs to regulate thirst and vasopressin release.
Thalamic relay for auditory information from the inferior colliculus to auditory cortex. Organized tonotopically for frequency-specific sound processing.
Epithalamic nucleus projecting to the interpeduncular nucleus via the fasciculus retroflexus. Involved in aversion, nicotine withdrawal, and fear processing.
Largest mammillary body subdivision relaying hippocampal information through the anterior thalamus. Critical for spatial and episodic memory consolidation.
Pacemaker for hippocampal theta rhythm via cholinergic and GABAergic projections. Essential for spatial learning and memory encoding.
Basal forebrain cholinergic and GABAergic neurons projecting to hippocampus and cortex. Modulates attention, arousal, and memory consolidation.
Ventral striatal structure receiving direct olfactory bulb input. Integrates olfactory and reward information; contains the Islands of Calleja.

full_name: Vascular organ of the lamina terminalis
description: Circumventricular organ lacking a blood-brain barrier. Senses blood osmolality and angiotensin II to regulate thirst and vasopressin secretion.
Pallidal cells not mapped to a specific nucleus. May reside in transitional pallidal zones.
Intralaminar thalamic nucleus involved in arousal and pain processing. Projects to the striatum and cortex to modulate attention and somatosensory integration.
Dorsal preoptic region at the diencephalic-telencephalic boundary. Involved in autonomic regulation and sleep-wake transitions.
Intralaminar thalamic nucleus with major striatal projections. Involved in attention, action monitoring, and behavioral switching; modulates cholinergic interneurons.
Caudal intralaminar nucleus relaying multisensory and nociceptive information. Projects to the amygdala and striatum for affective and motor processing.
Higher-order somatosensory thalamic relay integrating whisker and pain information. Projects to secondary somatosensory and motor cortices.
Thalamic nucleus at the caudal border of the thalamus. Involved in multisensory integration and nociceptive processing.
Small nucleus near the cerebral peduncle. Processes auditory and multisensory information with connections to the amygdala.
Small midline thalamic nucleus adjacent to nucleus reuniens. Contributes to hippocampal-prefrontal communication and contextual memory.
Preoptic region near the stria terminalis. Involved in reproductive and social behaviors via connections with the extended amygdala.
Small nucleus adjacent to the subthalamic nucleus. Involved in feeding behavior and autonomic regulation with hypothalamic and brainstem connections.
Hypothalamic nucleus lateral to the subthalamic nucleus. Contains neurons responsive to appetite-suppressing signals and stress.
Midline thalamic nucleus projecting to the nucleus accumbens and prefrontal cortex. Involved in reward processing and motivation.
Midline thalamic nucleus integrating stress, arousal, and reward signals. Projects to prefrontal cortex and nucleus accumbens; regulates emotional and motivated behavior.
Anterior periventricular zone containing neuroendocrine neurons. Involved in regulation of pituitary hormone release.
Hypothalamic region surrounding the fornix containing orexin neurons. Critical for arousal, feeding, and the fight-or-flight response.
Small posterior thalamic nucleus involved in multisensory processing. Relays auditory and somatosensory information to the cortex.
Hypothalamic region posterior to the optic chiasm. Contains scattered neurons involved in circadian and neuroendocrine regulation.
Midline thalamic nucleus providing the major thalamic input to the hippocampus. Critical for memory consolidation and hippocampal-prefrontal cortex communication.
Midline thalamic nucleus involved in arousal and limbic processing. Projects to prefrontal cortex and hippocampus to modulate attention and memory.
GABAergic shell surrounding the thalamus that gates thalamocortical information flow. Generates sleep spindles and regulates attentional filtering.
Hypothalamic region ventral to the paraventricular nucleus receiving SCN output. Relays circadian timing signals to regulate daily rhythms in behavior and physiology.
Small septal nucleus at the fimbria-fornix junction. Involved in modulating hippocampal activity and spatial memory processing.
Thalamic nucleus dorsal to the medial geniculate. Involved in multimodal sensory processing, particularly auditory and somatosensory integration.
Septal neurons projecting to the hippocampus. Part of the cholinergic and GABAergic circuitry supporting theta rhythm and memory.
Basal forebrain region containing cholinergic neurons of the nucleus basalis of Meynert. Provides cortical acetylcholine for attention and arousal; degenerates in Alzheimer's disease.
Small thalamic nucleus ventral to the mediodorsal nucleus. Projects to orbital cortex and involved in olfactory and visceral processing.
Region near the parafascicular nucleus in the thalamus. Involved in processing nociceptive and reproductive-related sensory information.
Thalamic nucleus with large neurons processing genital somatosensory information. Involved in reproductive physiology and ejaculation circuits.
Small-celled subdivision of the subparafascicular nucleus. Processes auditory and multimodal sensory information with limbic connections.
Striatal cells not mapped to a specific nucleus. May reside in transitional zones within the striatal complex.
Hypothalamic nucleus projecting to the hippocampus to modulate theta rhythm. Involved in spatial memory, arousal, and reward processing.
Small nucleus below the geniculate complex. Contributes to visual and multimodal sensory processing.
Thalamic cells not mapped to a specific nucleus. May reside in fiber tracts or transitional zones within the thalamus.
Contains histaminergic neurons that promote wakefulness. Projects broadly throughout the brain to maintain cortical arousal.
Ventral histaminergic population contributing to wake promotion. Works with the dorsal part to regulate the sleep-wake cycle.
Small septal nucleus involved in modulating hippocampal and limbic activity. Part of the septal complex regulating emotional and cognitive processing.
Motor thalamic relay receiving basal ganglia and cerebellar output. Critical for planning and execution of voluntary movements.
Primary sleep-promoting nucleus containing galanin/GABA neurons. Inhibits arousal centers during sleep; damage causes severe insomnia.
Motor thalamic nucleus receiving basal ganglia input. Involved in orofacial movements and motivated behavior via projections to motor and prefrontal cortex.
Preoptic region activated by inflammatory signals. Mediates fever response and sickness behavior through prostaglandin signaling.
Primary somatosensory thalamic relay for body sensation. Receives spinothalamic and dorsal column-medial lemniscus inputs for touch and pain.
Small-celled division of VPL processing nociceptive and thermal information. Projects to insular and secondary somatosensory cortex.
Primary somatosensory thalamic relay for face and oral cavity. Receives trigeminal inputs for whisker and facial touch sensation.
Gustatory thalamic relay receiving taste information from the brainstem. Projects to the insular gustatory cortex.
Midline thalamic nucleus at the ventral surface. Involved in fear memory retrieval and extinction via projections to prefrontal cortex and amygdala.
Pontine cells not mapped to a specific nucleus. May reside in transitional zones or fiber tracts within the pons.
Medullary cells not mapped to a specific nucleus. May reside in transitional zones or fiber tracts within the medulla.
Small motor nucleus supplementing the facial nerve. Contains neurons innervating a subset of facial muscles.
Motor nucleus innervating laryngeal and pharyngeal muscles for swallowing and vocalization. Also contains cardiac vagal neurons that regulate heart rate.
Circumventricular organ in the dorsal medulla lacking a blood-brain barrier. Acts as the chemoreceptor trigger zone for emesis and senses circulating toxins and hormones.
Small nucleus associated with the trigeminal motor system. Contributes to reflex jaw movements and proprioceptive processing from masticatory muscles.
Pontine micturition center controlling bladder function. Projects to sacral parasympathetic neurons to initiate urination.
Serotonergic nucleus in the pontine raphe. Modulates mood, anxiety, and sleep through widespread ascending projections.
Dorsal column relay for fine touch and proprioception from the upper body. Second-order sensory neurons project to the thalamus via the medial lemniscus.
Auditory brainstem nucleus receiving input from the cochlear nerve. Integrates auditory and somatosensory signals for sound localization and spectral processing.

full_name: Dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus
description: Parasympathetic preganglionic motor nucleus controlling visceral organs. Regulates gastrointestinal motility, secretion, and cardiac function via the vagus nerve.
Pontine nucleus involved in head direction signaling and spatial navigation. Receives vestibular and limbic inputs and projects to the mammillary bodies.
Relays proprioceptive information from the upper limbs to the cerebellum. Equivalent of Clarke's column for forelimb spinocerebellar input.
Largest medullary reticular formation nucleus with diverse motor and autonomic functions. Contains neurons involved in posture, locomotion, and cardiovascular regulation.
Small nucleus between the trigeminal motor and principal sensory nuclei. Involved in trigeminal reflex circuits and orofacial sensorimotor integration.
Small nucleus at the ventral border of the cerebellum. Contributes to cerebellar input processing and vestibular-cerebellar communication.
Principal source of climbing fibers to the cerebellar cortex. Critical for motor learning, error correction, and timing of coordinated movements.
Medullary reticular formation involved in autonomic regulation and premotor functions. Contains interneurons coordinating respiratory, cardiovascular, and orofacial motor patterns.
Parasympathetic nucleus providing preganglionic innervation to the parotid gland via the glossopharyngeal nerve. Regulates salivary secretion.
Vestibular nucleus (Deiters' nucleus) controlling postural reflexes. Projects to the spinal cord via the lateral vestibulospinal tract to maintain balance and upright posture.
Principal noradrenergic nucleus of the brain with widespread projections. Modulates arousal, attention, stress responses, and memory consolidation.
Cholinergic and glutamatergic nucleus involved in REM sleep regulation and reward. Projects to the ventral tegmental area and thalamus to modulate arousal states.
Small reticular formation nucleus in the medulla. Contributes to autonomic and motor integration within the brainstem reticular network.
Precerebellar nucleus relaying spinal and brainstem motor information to the cerebellum. Important for limb coordination and motor adaptation.
Large-celled reticular formation nucleus involved in motor coordination. Contains neurons with widespread projections modulating spinal motor circuits.
Caudal reticular formation involved in autonomic and somatic motor functions. Contains interneurons coordinating reflexes and rhythmic motor patterns.
Largest vestibular nucleus processing signals from semicircular canals. Mediates the vestibulo-ocular reflex and coordinates eye-head movements.
Pontine nucleus containing relaxin-3 neurons. Modulates arousal, stress responses, hippocampal theta rhythm, and feeding behavior.
Auditory relay nuclei along the lateral lemniscus pathway. Processes temporal features of sound including gap detection and amplitude modulation.
Small nucleus near the hypoglossal nucleus. Involved in orofacial motor control and vestibular-related reflexes.
Auditory brainstem nucleus containing principal neurons of the medial superior olive circuit. Critical for computing interaural time differences for sound localization.
Primary visceral sensory nucleus receiving taste and cardiorespiratory afferents. Integrates gustatory, baroreceptor, and chemoreceptor information for autonomic regulation.
Region surrounding the trigeminal nuclei containing scattered neurons. Involved in modulation of trigeminal sensory processing and orofacial pain.
Small-celled reticular formation involved in orofacial motor control and autonomic function. Contains premotor neurons for facial, hypoglossal, and trigeminal motor nuclei.
Small nucleus adjacent to the solitary tract. Processes visceral sensory information and contributes to autonomic reflex circuits.
Pontine relay for visceral sensory information including taste, pain, and temperature. Projects to the amygdala, hypothalamus, and thalamus for interoceptive processing.
Small-celled division of the trigeminal motor nucleus. Controls fine movements of the jaw and contributes to masticatory reflexes.
Periventricular gray matter of the pons. Involved in pain modulation, defensive behaviors, and autonomic regulation, similar to the periaqueductal gray.
Pontine tegmental nucleus involved in sleep-wake regulation. Contains neurons modulating arousal state transitions and REM sleep.
Corticopontine relay nuclei projecting mossy fibers to the cerebellum. Receives massive cortical input and is critical for cerebellar motor learning and coordination.
Dorsal division of the paragigantocellular nucleus. Involved in cardiovascular regulation and sympathetic control of blood pressure.
Lateral reticular formation adjacent to the gigantocellular nucleus. Contains premotor sympathetic neurons and respiratory interneurons.
Medullary nucleus near the pyramidal tract containing serotonergic neurons. Involved in respiratory modulation and sympathetic regulation.
Caudal pontine reticular formation involved in motor coordination and startle reflexes. Contains neurons mediating the acoustic startle response and postural control.
Oral (rostral) pontine reticular formation involved in REM sleep and motor control. Contains neurons generating rapid eye movements and muscle atonia during REM.
Nucleus prepositus hypoglossi involved in gaze holding and eye position signals. Acts as a neural integrator converting eye velocity to position commands.

full_name: Principal sensory nucleus of the trigeminal
description: Primary relay for fine touch and tactile discrimination from the face. Equivalent of the dorsal column nuclei for trigeminal somatosensory information.
Small nucleus adjacent to the spinal trigeminal tract. Processes visceral and nociceptive information from the face and upper airway.
Serotonergic medullary raphe nucleus involved in descending pain modulation. Projects to the spinal dorsal horn to gate nociceptive transmission.
Serotonergic raphe nucleus projecting to the spinal cord and brainstem. Modulates autonomic functions including respiratory rhythm and sympathetic outflow.
Caudal serotonergic raphe nucleus projecting to the spinal cord. Involved in thermoregulation, particularly activation of brown adipose tissue for heat generation.
Pontine serotonergic raphe nucleus with projections to the cerebellum. Modulates cerebellar processing and contributes to motor coordination.
Small pontine nucleus near the genu of the facial nerve. Involved in vestibular processing and eye movement coordination.
Pontine nucleus adjacent to the locus coeruleus. Contains noradrenergic and other neurons contributing to arousal and REM sleep regulation.
Pontine nucleus critical for generating REM sleep muscle atonia. Glutamatergic neurons project to inhibitory spinal interneurons to suppress movement during dreaming.
Auditory brainstem nuclei computing interaural time and level differences for sound localization. First station for binaural hearing in the ascending auditory pathway.
Caudal vestibular nucleus extending into the upper spinal cord. Processes vestibular signals for postural reflexes and vestibulospinal motor control.

full_name: Spinal nucleus of the trigeminal caudal part
description: Caudal division processing pain and temperature from the face. Functionally analogous to the spinal dorsal horn for trigeminal nociception.

full_name: Spinal nucleus of the trigeminal interpolar part
description: Intermediate division of the spinal trigeminal nucleus. Processes dental pain and contributes to orofacial reflex circuits.

full_name: Spinal nucleus of the trigeminal oral part
description: Rostral division processing tactile and nociceptive information from the oral cavity. Involved in intraoral sensorimotor integration and dental reflexes.
Nucleus dorsal to the trigeminal motor nucleus. Contains interneurons for jaw-opening reflexes and coordination of mastication.
Vestibular nucleus primarily receiving semicircular canal input. Mediates the vestibulo-ocular reflex and projects to oculomotor nuclei for gaze stabilization.
Pontine reticular nucleus projecting to the cerebellum and oculomotor centers. Involved in saccadic eye movements and cerebellar-dependent motor learning.
Motor nucleus innervating muscles of mastication via the trigeminal nerve. Controls jaw opening, closing, and lateral movements for chewing.
Auditory brainstem nucleus receiving primary cochlear nerve input. Contains diverse neuron types that encode different temporal and spectral features of sound.
Motor nucleus innervating the lateral rectus muscle for eye abduction. Also contains internuclear neurons coordinating conjugate horizontal eye movements.
Motor nucleus innervating muscles of facial expression via the facial nerve. Controls blinking, lip movements, and emotional facial expressions.
Motor nucleus innervating tongue muscles via the hypoglossal nerve. Essential for tongue movements during speech, swallowing, and feeding.
Small reticular formation nucleus in the medulla. Part of the brainstem reticular network contributing to autonomic and motor integration.
Small nucleus associated with the vestibular complex. Involved in vestibulo-cerebellar processing and eye movement coordination.
Midbrain cells not mapped to a specific nucleus. May reside in transitional zones or fiber tracts within the midbrain.
Deep layers of the superior colliculus generating orienting movements of the eyes, head, and body toward salient stimuli. Integrates multisensory inputs to drive saccades and defensive responses.
Superficial layers of the superior colliculus receiving direct retinal input. Constructs a retinotopic map of visual space for detecting and localizing visual stimuli.
Principal midbrain auditory relay integrating ascending inputs from multiple brainstem nuclei. Organized tonotopically and critical for sound localization and temporal processing.
Central gray matter surrounding the cerebral aqueduct. Master coordinator of defensive behaviors, pain modulation, vocalization, and autonomic responses via descending projections.
Reticular formation of the midbrain involved in arousal, locomotion, and posture. Contains neurons modulating ascending and descending motor and sensory pathways.
Pretectal nucleus involved in nociceptive modulation and somatosensory processing. Produces descending analgesia and modulates spinal pain transmission.
Principal output nucleus of the basal ganglia sending tonic GABAergic inhibition to the thalamus and superior colliculus. Disinhibition permits voluntary movement initiation.
Contains dopaminergic neurons projecting to the dorsal striatum via the nigrostriatal pathway. Degeneration of these neurons causes Parkinson's disease motor symptoms.
Major source of mesolimbic and mesocortical dopamine projecting to nucleus accumbens and prefrontal cortex. Central to reward, motivation, and reinforcement learning.
Cholinergic and glutamatergic brainstem nucleus at the midbrain-pons junction. Involved in locomotion, arousal, and REM sleep; a target for deep brain stimulation in gait disorders.
Midbrain nucleus in the locomotor region involved in initiating and modulating locomotion. Also participates in defensive and escape behaviors via PAG connections.
Midbrain motor nucleus receiving cerebellar and cortical input. Contributes to limb motor control via the rubrospinal tract, particularly in reaching and grasping movements.
Midline nucleus receiving the fasciculus retroflexus from the habenula. Involved in aversion, fear, nicotine withdrawal, and modulation of dopaminergic and serotonergic systems.
Small nucleus associated with the posterior commissure fiber tract. Involved in pupillary light reflex and vertical gaze coordination.
Pretectal nucleus receiving direct retinal input. Drives the optokinetic reflex for image stabilization during slow head movements.
Largest serotonergic nucleus in the brain with widespread ascending projections. Modulates mood, anxiety, reward, sleep, and feeding; primary target of SSRI antidepressants.
Pretectal nucleus involved in visual processing and pupillary responses. Contributes to the pretectal circuitry for luminance detection and pupillary constriction.
Dopaminergic cell group (A8) caudal to the substantia nigra. Supplements nigrostriatal and mesolimbic dopamine projections involved in motor and motivational functions.

full_name: Nucleus of the brachium of the inferior colliculus
description: Relay nucleus in the auditory pathway connecting the inferior colliculus to the medial geniculate body. Processes auditory information ascending to the thalamus.
Small nucleus in the lateral midbrain tegmentum near the lateral lemniscus. Involved in auditory processing and multisensory integration.
Midline raphe nucleus containing dopaminergic and serotonergic neurons. Part of the ventral tegmental dopamine system contributing to reward and motivation circuits.
Raphe nucleus containing dopaminergic neurons adjacent to the VTA. Contributes to the mesolimbic dopamine system and modulates reward processing.
Cholinergic nucleus reciprocally connected with the superior colliculus. Modulates visual attention and enhances stimulus detection in the tectal visual map.
Small tegmental nucleus in the ventral midbrain. Involved in limbic-motor integration and connected with the mammillary bodies and hypothalamus.
Tegmental nucleus involved in spatial navigation and head direction signaling. Relays vestibular and cerebellar information to the mammillary bodies.
Raphe nucleus containing dopaminergic and serotonergic neurons. Part of the ventral midbrain dopamine system with projections to limbic structures.
Pretectal region involved in visual processing and pupillary reflexes. Receives retinal input and contributes to non-image-forming visual functions.

full_name: Medial terminal nucleus of the accessory optic tract
description: Accessory optic nucleus detecting global visual motion for image stabilization. Drives compensatory eye movements in response to self-motion.
Central nucleus in the pupillary light reflex pathway receiving bilateral retinal input. Projects to the Edinger-Westphal nucleus to drive pupillary constriction.

full_name: Lateral terminal nucleus of the accessory optic tract
description: Accessory optic nucleus encoding global visual motion. Contributes to optokinetic and vestibulo-ocular reflexes for retinal image stabilization.
Motor nucleus innervating four of six extraocular muscles plus the levator palpebrae. Controls most voluntary eye movements and eyelid elevation.
Small nucleus posterior to the parafascicular nucleus. Involved in nociceptive processing and autonomic regulation via connections with the thalamus and hypothalamus.
Ependymal secretory organ at the entrance to the cerebral aqueduct. Produces SCO-spondin glycoprotein involved in cerebrospinal fluid homeostasis and brain development.
Dopaminergic cell group medial to the VTA. Part of the mesolimbic dopamine system projecting to limbic structures for reward and motivational processing.
Small nucleus adjacent to the trochlear nucleus. Contains accessory oculomotor neurons involved in coordinating eye movements.
Parasympathetic preganglionic nucleus controlling pupillary constriction and lens accommodation. Also contains centrally projecting urocortin neurons involved in stress and feeding.
Accessory nucleus associated with the oculomotor complex. Contains neurons coordinating vergence eye movements and near-response accommodation.

full_name: Dorsal terminal nucleus of the accessory optic tract
description: Accessory optic nucleus detecting vertical global visual motion. Contributes to compensatory eye movements for retinal image stabilization during vertical head movements.
Smallest cranial nerve motor nucleus innervating the superior oblique muscle. Unique in that its axons decussate and exit dorsally from the brainstem.
